chapter.title: Questions and Answers
chapter.para: We advice you to read also the user documentation - especially the tricks, tips & tools - chapter.

sect2.title: What is SUMO?
sect2.para: Answer: SUMO is a traffic simulation package. It is meant to be used to simulate networks of a city's size, but you can of course use it for smaller networks and larger, too, if your computer power is large enough.

sect2.title: What does "SUMO" mean?
sect2.para: Answer: "SUMO" is an acronym for "Simulation of Urban MObility".

sect2.title: What kind of a traffic simulation is SUMO?
sect2.para: Question: What kind of a traffic simulation is SUMO?
Answer: SUMO is a microscopic, space-continuous road traffic simulation. In the next time it will be extended to be multi-modal.

sect3.title: moc-files not found
sect3.para: Question: For the GUI project I didn’t find files such as "moc_GUIApplicationWindow.cpp" (there are seven files beginning with “moc_” ). If I delete them, I have some link errors like : error LNK2001: unresolved external symbol "protected: virtual void __thiscall GUIApplicationWindow::initMetaObject(void)" (?initMetaObject@GUIApplicationWindow@@MAEXXZ)
Do you have any suggestions to resolve this problem ?

Answer: Yes, those files are used by the Qt-library (www.troll-tech.com) and are build automatically. If you take a look into the project settings (MSVC++: project->settings->gui) and open the file browser within this window, some .h-files have another icon. If you click on one of these and choose the "user defined building" (I do not exactly know how it is called in english), you will see some additional program calls.

To build the gui, you have to install Qt2.3 which includes some additional programs within a bin-folder, automatically installed. Set the environment variable "QTDIR" to the folder you have installed Qt into (not to the bin-folder as you may see from the calls within the project). This should let MSVC++ build the moc*-files first.

sect2.title: Traffic within junctions
sect2.para: Question: Does SUMO support traffic within the junctions?
No, not yet. There is an approach towards this, but it is not yet in such a stable state that it would be useable.

sect2.title: Connection with an external application
sect2.para: Question: Is it possible to connect SUMO to an external application (f.e. ns-2)?

No, not yet. We have build an internal version which handles connections to other applications, but it's not yet available as open source. So in principle, it is possible, but there is nothing that does it within the current code.

sect3.title: Strange and cryptic Errors
sect3.para: Question: What does the following error mean?

Warning: No types defined, using defaults... Error: An exception occurred! Type:RuntimeException, Message:The primary document entity could not be opened. Id=<PATH> Error: (At line/column 1/0). Error: Quitting (conversion failed).
Answer: Simply that the file you try to use (<PATH>) does not exist. This is xercec' way to say "file not found".

sect3.title: The application hangs after a while (few memory consumption, most of the system time)
sect3.para: Question: When I start the SUMO-NETCONVERT with large networks, the system hangs after a while. The program uses most of the system time, but when I look into the task manager almost no memory is used.

Answer: You are propably running a program compiled in the debug-mode. This yields in at least the triple of normal memory usage and your system may not be able to solve. Try to use the normal version, build in Release-mode (or buy more RAM :-) ).

sect3.title: No random routes are generated
sect3.para: Question: I have tried to insert vehicles using the -R option, but the route file is empty.

Answer: On the one hand, SUMO-routers quit processing if a route could not be build. On the other hand, the generation of a random route may fail quite easily, simply because it's too short or no connection could have been found. If you have made everything right, but your route file is empty, try to use the --continue-on-unbuild switch on your command line / within your configuration file.

sect3.title: Network changes
sect3.para: Question: I have changed my network and now SUMO does not load it.

Answer: Actually, SUMO-networks are not meant to be edited by hand. You have to describe everything within the your input properly and let NETVCONVERT build your network. Editing networks by hand is very complicated and error-proned.

sect3.title: No vehicle appears
sect3.para: Question: I have build the network and routes like described, but no vehicle can be seen)

Answer: We encountered this problem under the following circumstances: As we imported a network where the maximum speed allowed on was given in km/h instead of the supposed m/s, no vehicle could be emitted due to a too large space needed for oncoming traffic. Check whether your network description also defines speed in km/h. If so, use the SUMO-NETCONVERT - switch "speed-in-km" to recompute the speed limits. If this does not help, contact us.

sect3.title: Vehicle jumps backward
sect3.para: Question: When I try to evaluate my vehicle dump, sometimes vehicle seem to jump backward (their position is smaller than in the previous step)

Answer: To avoid jams due to an inappropriate lane changing behaviour, vehicles may swap their lanes. In this case each vehicle obtains the position and speed of the other vehicle. As the position of the vehicles may differ a bit, one of the vehicles may seem to jump backwards.
Remark: This should not happen from Version0.8 on.

sect3.title: Display flickers in the area of the mouse pointer
sect3.para: Question: Why is the view around the mouse pointer distorted?

Answer: Newer Windows-Versions seem to cache the area under the mouse to apply the mouse shadow afterwards. To avoid this, go to your Systemmenu, then Mouse->Pointers and disable the mouse shadows. That's the only solution so far. (Origin: Till Oliver Knoll, via QT Interest List)
